articles.author: James Patter
articles.description:
30 Things I Wish I Knew Before I Started Web Development
Maksym Kunytskyi „Éª May 31
#webdev
        #javascript
        #programming
        #productivity
articles.title: [Boost]

articles.author: Maksym Kunytskyi
articles.description:
After years of building products, mentoring, and making (a lot of) mistakes, I decided to write this list.
Whether you're just starting or already on your journey, I hope this helps you avoid a few traps and move faster.
You don‚Äôt need to know everything before building.


You‚Äôll learn the most by doing ‚Äî not by waiting until you feel ‚Äúready.‚Äù
HTML and CSS are more powerful (and complex) than you think.


Layouts, responsiveness, and browser quirks take time to master.
JavaScript will confuse you ‚Äî that‚Äôs normal.


Scopes, closures, and async logic are tough at first, but clarity comes with practice.
You can break production with a missing semicolon.


Small mistakes can have big consequences ‚Äî attention to detail matters.
Frameworks change, fundamentals don‚Äôt.


Learn the core web concept‚Ä¶
articles.title: 30 Things I Wish I Knew Before I Started Web Development

articles.author: datatoinfinity
articles.description:
Almost every software or technology revolves around four basic functions: Create, Retrieve, Update, and Delete‚Äîcollectively known as CRUD operations.
Same is going with lists also, we are going to perform adding, modifying and retrieving method on list which is built in function.
1. append(): Basically it adds value at the end of the list.
2. clear(): As name suggest it simply clear the list.
3. copy(): Basically copy the original list and we can make changes in copied list which doesn't effect the original one.
4. count(): It shows how many times specific value is been repeated.
5. extend(): It add two list.
6. index(): It used to find the index of value in a list.
7. insert(): It is used for adding value in list with there position.
8. pop(): It will remove the value from the list according to its position.
9. remove(): It removes with help from there name and it remove first occurrence.
10. reverse(): It reverse the order of the list.
11. sort(): sort the list in ascending order by default.


fruits=['apple','cherry','banana','cherry']
fruits.sort()
print(fruits)



['apple', 'banana', 'cherry', 'cherry']
articles.title: Lists Methods

articles.author: Satyabrata
articles.description:
Building apps powered by AI is easier than ever, thanks to a new breed of tools called MCP servers. If you‚Äôve ever wished your coding assistant could fetch information, organize your data, or search the web for you, MCP servers are here to make that a reality. This article breaks down what MCP servers are, how they work, and introduces three of the most practical servers‚ÄîCrawl4AI RAG, Supabase, and Brave Search‚Äîthat can supercharge your app development workflow.
MCP stands for Model Context Protocol. In simple terms, MCP servers act as bridges between AI tools (like coding assistants or chatbots) and external resources such as databases, web search engines, or file systems. They give your AI assistant new ‚Äúsuperpowers‚Äù‚Äîletting it look up documentation, manage data, or fetch live informatio‚Ä¶
articles.title: These MCP Servers Will Build Your Apps with Ease: A Complete Guide

articles.title: üöÄ Chat With AI on Your Terminal ‚Äì No API Key, No Limits, Just Python + Ollama

articles.author: Emma(minjoo)
articles.description:
Graphs


A tree is actually a type of graph, but not all graphs are trees. Simply put, a tree is a connected graphs without cycles.

A graph is simply a collection of nodes with edges between (some of) them  
graphs can be either directed (like the following graph) or undirected. While directed edges are like a one-way street, undirected edges are like a two-way street.
The graph might consist of multiple isolated subgraphs. If there is a path between every pair of vertices, it is called a "connected graph"
the graph can also have cycles. An "acyclic graph" is one without cycles




  
  
  Adjacency List


This is the most common way to represent a graph. Every vertes(or node) stores a list of adjacent vertices. In an undirected graph, an edge like(a,b) would be stored twice : once in a's adjacent vertices and once in b's adjacent vertices.  
In order to implement of simple graph, the graph class is used because, unlike in a tree, you can't necessarily reach all the nodes from a single node. You don't necessarily need any additional classes to represent a graph. An array(or a hash table) of lists(arrays, arraylists, linked lists, etc.) can store the adjacency list.
But it isn't quite as clean. We tend to use node classes unless there's a compelling reason not to.
An adjacency matrix is an NxN boolean matrix (where N is the number of nodes), where a true value at matrix[i][j] indecates an edge from node i to node j( you can also use an integer matrix with 0s and 1s.)

In an undirected graph, an adjacency matrix will be symmetric. In a directed graph, it will not(necessarily)be.
articles.title: Data structure - Graph

articles.author: logarithmicspirals
articles.description:
Introduction


In a previous post, I described how I created a "Similar Posts" component for my blog. Originally, that was going to be a one-shot post. After deploying the new feature, I noticed that some of the recommended posts were irrelevant.
Shortly after publishing my last post, I was surfing the web and came across something I had not considered while implementing my "Similar Posts" feature. For example, when I was looking at my previous article AMD RX 6700 XT Overclocking: Unlocking Max Performance I noticed the following posts were displayed as similar:

While the first post seemed reasonable, I thought the other two seemed unrelated. This observation sent me on a search to determine if there was something I was missing. While asking ChatGPT, it suggested I should try to set a thr‚Ä¶
articles.title: Refining ‚ÄúSimilar Posts‚Äù for Relevance and Simplicity

articles.author: Justin K T
articles.description:
I first wrote this piece on Medium as part of documenting my cybersecurity journey. Reposting it here for broader reach and engagement.
Quick note before we begin, I am an aspiring offensive security professional with a growing portfolio of certifications and hands-on experience, particularly through platforms like INE (formerly eLearnSecurity), TryHackMe, and HackTheBox. While I have made significant progress in my learning journey, I am still early in my career. This review reflects my personal experiences and observations so far, and I highly encourage readers to consider multiple perspectives when planning their own cybersecurity education paths.
This topic is important because many newcomers to cybersecurity face the same dilemma: Should I pursue a degree, stack certifications, or div‚Ä¶
articles.title: From Classroom to HackTheBox: My Journey Through Cybersecurity Degree, Certifications, and the Power of Practical Experience

articles.author: Rahul Gupta
articles.description:
In our last post, we introduced you to NativePHP, a powerful tool that lets you build native desktop applications using Laravel. Today, we‚Äôre getting our hands dirty and setting up our very first NativePHP app‚Äîfrom scratch.
Let‚Äôs bring Laravel from the browser to the desktop.
Before we begin, make sure you have the following tools installed on your machine:
PHP 8.1+


Composer


Node.js & NPM


Laravel (v10 or above recommended)


Git


Electron Builder (will be handled via NativePHP)



You can check versions with:
php -v
composer -V
node -v
npm -v

If you don‚Äôt already have a Laravel project, let‚Äôs create one:
composer create-project laravel/laravel nativephp-demo
cd nativephp-demo

Or you can use an existing Laravel app.
Now, install the NativePHP Electron package:
composer require nati‚Ä¶
articles.title: Setting Up Your First NativePHP Project in Laravel

articles.author: Ali nazari
articles.description:
Securing your Redis deployment is crucial once you begin relying on it for caching, messaging, or as a primary datastore. 
Redis 6 introduced an ACL (Access Control List) system that allows you to lock down commands and keys per user. 
However, enabling ACLs often trips up monitoring tools like Redis Insight, which by default attempt to connect without credentials.
In this post, we‚Äôll walk through everything‚Äîfrom writing valid ACL definitions to integrating Redis Insight in Docker‚Äîensuring you end up with a secure, fully observable Redis setup. 
Redis Insight, when installed on its own or bundled inside a ‚ÄúRedis Stack‚Äù container, assumes it can connect anonymously (no username, no password). 
As soon as you enable an ACL file, the built-in default user has no permissions (or is turned off)‚Ä¶
articles.title: Securing Redis with ACLs and Integrating Redis Insight in Docker

articles.author: mridul bansal
articles.description:
These last 4 days were not dramatic

But they were real

I got back to basics and I built some solid momentum
First I fully completed Git and GitHub

Not half-learned but properly understood

Branching merging pushing pulling resolving conflicts

Now I can say I actually know version control
Then I sat with React js

Practiced component structures

Worked with state and props

Started getting used to useState and useEffect

It‚Äôs still new but not scary anymore

Tailwind CSS also felt overwhelming at first

But after building with it for hours

I started feeling comfortable with the utility classes
I also went back to DSA

I did not rush through 20 questions a day

I solved 3 to 4 properly

Understood logic dry ran them

And moved only when I actually got it
In the middle of this I finished the book Think Straight

It gave me mental clarity

Helped me remove unnecessary thoughts

Sometimes the problem is not what to do

The problem is we think too much

And this book cleared that clutter
But to be honest I still wasted some time

Some mental baggage

Some emotional slipups

Some lost hours that I should‚Äôve used

And I accept that

No filters no excuses

It is what it is
But I also know this

This was not failure

This was a checkpoint

A small reset

A small loss to trigger a bigger win
Now I am standing at the start of the last 60 days

And I am not here to play
From tomorrow I go all in

Solo grind

No noise

No distractions

Just pure build mode
## Gameplan



Write code daily without skipping

Finish React and Tailwind projects

Push everything to GitHub in proper structure

Practice DSA with quality and depth

Keep reading but only when I apply what I learn

Track execution daily

Improve every area step by step

No burnouts

No breakdowns

Just quiet ruthless building
### Final thought


I don‚Äôt want this blog to be motivation

This is documentation

Because I am not here to impress

I am here to finish what I started

These 60 days are mine

And I will make them count
articles.title: Day 39 ‚Äì Locked Reloaded Ready to Devour the Last 60 Days
